awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Reimagining Sketch in the Digital Age
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project results from the development  of a new class of graphical-media-design system that lies between today's 2D digital paint systems and 3D computer-aided design systems. This technology will allow architects, engineers, artists, and school children to create compelling 3D experiences directly from their drawings without extensive training. Furthermore, it will accelerate the creation of interactive 3D content and significantly reduce the time, cost and expertise currently required to create it. By bridging the gap between traditional drawings and 3D modeling, this project will provide the unique ability to reuse and "reproject" drawn strokes, thus enabling the creation of expressive 3D drawings with minimal effort. The technology developed in this project will help lower the barrier and generate new business opportunities in content creation for electronic publishing and for other creative professionals, such as architects, designers, and ad-agency art directors. Finally, this project includes specific outreach activities, through collaboration with the American Museum of Natural History, that will provide unique educational services to the local community, while simultaneously introducing this new technology to the world.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will focus on making the creation of this new type of graphical media as intuitive and fluid as paper and pencil. This Phase II project will support system improvements - including user-interface improvements - to simplify 3D navigation for the consumers of this media. This will be needed for using this media in digital children's picture books, which have already been identified as early adopters of this technology as well as an important market. Another technical objective will be to develop a hybrid vector-raster representation, which will provide a wider range of artistic expression, while improving rendering performance of large scenes. A third objective is to develop stroke deformation algorithms to support direct manipulation of objects and characters to provide sketch-driven animation capabilities.

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is around the development of a new class of graphical-media-design system that lies between today's 2D digital paint systems and 3D computer-aided design systems. This technology allows architects, engineers, artists, and school children to create compelling 3D experiences directly from their drawings without extensive training. Furthermore, it accelerates the creation of interactive 3D content and significantly reduces the time, cost and expertise currently required to create it. By bridging the gap between traditional drawings and 3D modeling, this technology provides the unique ability to reuse and "reproject" drawn strokes, thus enabling the creation of expressive 3D drawings with minimal effort. The technology developed in this project is helping to lower the barrier and generate new business opportunities in content creation for electronic publishing and for other creative professionals, such as architects, designers, and ad-agency art directors. 

The graphical media or "spatial drawings," created with the technology and shareable via a custom web player, is finding application in a range of settings, including visual storytelling and advertising.  This media is far more engaging than other forms of advertising, such as images or videos, and therefore offers a number of business opportunities.

This project focused on making the creation of this new type of graphical media as intuitive and fluid to use and manipulate as paper and pencil. The project supported system improvements - including user-interface improvements - to simplify 3D navigation for the consumers of this media. An early use case involved using this media in digital children's picture books, which were identified as early adopters of this technology as well as an important market. Another technical objective was to develop a hybrid vector-raster representation, which affords a wider range of artistic expression, while improving rendering performance of large scenes. A third objective was to develop stroke deformation algorithms to support direct manipulation of objects and characters to provide sketch-driven animation capabilities.

We were successful in meeting these objectives. Moreover, the technology has found application in a wide range of application domains -- from architecture to engineering to entertainment to advertising.
